data.title: Order of edit changes in TextDocumentChangeEvent.contentChanges is reverse the order of the actual edits
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version:10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create an edit with an insert and a remove
2. In the corresponding onDidChangeTextDocument event, look at the `TextDocumentChangeEvent.contentChanges` Notice how the order is reverse the order of the actual edit order.

data.title: Add a show "hidden" button to the file explorer

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.5.0-insider (1.5.0-insider)` 1de4d832ccb061c13cf70eaf0221fbaa86abfbdd
- OS Version: `OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.6 (15G31)`

I often have `node_modules` and `typings` (as well as others) hidden from the vscode file explorer, but it would be nice to be able to easily toggle them back to visible without having to edit my settings file for a transient check.

data.title: [decorators] Visible whitespace conflicts with before decorator attachment
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.5.0-insider (1.5.0-insider)` 1de4d832ccb061c13cf70eaf0221fbaa86abfbdd
- OS Version: `OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.6 (15G31)`

I'm working on a new extension [GitLens](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens) with a feature to provide "inline" blame support to the active text editor. I have it working quite well now, except for when Visible Whitespace is enabled. See the following:

It works quite well with whitespace hidden:

> ![no-visible-whitespace](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/641685/18221809/e3cedcf6-7152-11e6-8bce-76b81ed604c3.png)

Unfortunately with Whitespace visible, not so much:

> ![visible-whitespace](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/641685/18221815/0328178e-7153-11e6-8a66-ccac5a891839.png)

I've tracked it down to the inline `width` style that is added to the `leading whitespace` span. If that inline style is changed to `min-width` everything works, but I'm not sure on the ripple effect. Nor could I find exactly where that inline style is being added -- it looks like it starts in [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/973c3bdae5cb6ef1117773a6fd5168765c785438/src/vs/editor/common/viewLayout/viewLineParts.ts#L103). Another option is to remove `inline-block` from `.monaco-editor .token.whitespace` which also fixes the issue.

I am currently working on this in a branch, but you can find the code that sets up the decorations [here](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/blob/feature-blame-highlight/src/gitBlameController.ts).

Any help on this would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,
Eric Amodio

data.title: [Question] Is it safe to adjust the language name in my extension
data.body:
Hi, 

I just wanted to ask a quick question, I figured this was the best place. I made the Sass (Indented) extension and have seen since 1.3 that the built in **Scss** was renamed from **Sass** to **Scss** to reflect the actual support.

I was wondering if it would be safe for me to drop the (Indented) now and just use Sass for my extension or is there a risk it could still cause clashes or cause problems with other extensions?

Thanks

data.title: How to define a _focused/pre-selected_ item in showQuickPick?
data.body:
Is there a way to use `showQuickPick` and have the same behavior as **File / Open Recent**, that shows a list of items but the _focused/pre-selected_ item is not the first (in this case, it's the second, because the first is the current folder).

I searched for something in `QuickPickItem` or `QuickPickOptions`, but didn't find anything that could do that.

Thanks in advance

data.title: Autodetecting gulpfile.ts tasks
data.body: As it seems, VS Code does only detect gulpfile.js tasks but not gulpfile.ts tasks. Would be nice if it works with a .ts file as well.

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Use float with inline-block and it will mark it as nonvalid code 
2.  The float property is ignored with inline-block which is not the case even in legacy engines like IE9

- OS Version:Windows 10

If you have an indented header (below 2 spaces), all following Markdown does not have syntax highlighting.

~~~md

``` json

```
- item1
- item2
~~~

data.title: lock scroll in integrated terminal
data.body:
Would be nice if it is possible to set an option "lock scroll" in the integrated terminal (similar as in Eclipse) so that one can stop at a certain line and read on while output is written to the terminal below. 
In contrast to the current behaviour where one cannot stop and the terminal keeps on scrolling down.

data.title: Can't insert a tab at the end of a line in a jade file
data.body:
Have a jade file with this content-

```
extends layout

block content
  h1= title
  p Welcome to #{title}
```

Put the cursor directly after layout, content, or title, and press tab, and nothing happens. If you type a space, then you can insert a tab.

If the cursor is after the } in the last line, pressing tab will replace the braces with spaces and move the cursor next to the #.

data.title: Undo last commit should warn user if they have uncommited changes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
- Choose any git repo, add a file `test.js` with the following content

``` js
var foo = 1;
var bar = 2;
```

Add the file and commit it.
- Remove the second line, so the file ends up with:

``` js
var foo = 1;
```
- In VSCode's git viewlet, choose `Undo Last Commit`

Now the file is:

``` js
var foo = 1;
```

and this bit

``` js
var bar = 2;
```

is permanently lost.

Suggestions:
1. If user has uncommited changes, prompt him to stash before doing Undo Last Commit. Or
2. Use `git reset --soft` instead of `git reset`, which defaults to `--mixed`. In this case, when user has staged but uncommited changes, prompt him to either commit or unstage them.
   The benefit of using `--soft` this way is all last commit changes will end up in staged mode, whereas any local changes won't. So user could select which change they want, if the same file is edited both on last commit and locally.

data.title: PHP one-line functions syntax highlighting
data.body:
If I use one-line functions in my PHP files, they don't get highlighted. If I use new lines, the highlighting works as espected. Is it possible to fix this?

![screenshot](https://i.imgur.com/keW7JJj.png)

data.title: Find/Replace button in search pane opens a preview diff after applying the replace
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4 or 1.5-insiders
- OS Version: Win/OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the find pane on the side and do a global find/replace for anything
2. There are a list of results. When you click an item in the list, it opens a diff editor showing the effect of the find/replace. This is correct.
3. When you hover the cursor over an item, a button appears on the right side which you can click to apply the replacement. Click this.
4. It applies the replace to the file then opens a preview diff which doesn't show anything, since the change is applied.

It also opens the file where the replace happened, and I expect that, but not the preview diff.

Related to #11321

data.title: Debug console

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This item is intended as a discussion for the future of the debug console. Currently we use the tree to represent all elements in the debug console. This has worked well thus far but has certain limitations. The benefit of using the tree is that we can easily render complex elements - the ones that have children. The tree also allows us to lazily fetch the children of each element and is virtualised.
### Motivation for the change

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1957
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4338
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4326
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2163
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6845
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/228
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10680
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/26641

### Option 1: use the editor and simulate the tree using editor decorations

**pro:** find, selection, word wrap, performance
**con:** have to simulate the tree by using editor decorations / indentation, not enough flexibility (for possibly future requests of rendering custom things in the debug console). 

Note: editor could be enhanced to render custom images, but customly rendered output which the user can interact with is tricky.
### Option 2: use the editor but render a tree per complex object in a custom editor widget

**pro:** most similar to what we currently have with some benefits on top (able to find/copy outside of complex objects)
**con:** find and selection will not work inside the tree, thus making it hard to copy / find contents inside complex objects
### Option 3: render the debug console not using existing widgets

**pro:** gives most flexibility
**con:** no virtualisation, slow for a large number of elements, have to rewrite find widget, word wraping

Chrome debug console is a good example of this. They can render multiple complex elements side by side and expand / collapse them.

@weinand @alexandrudima please edit / modify as you see fit. I might have missed some of the pro/cons that we discussed, I just simply wrote what we have talked about this afternoon.

data.body:
_From @joaomoreno on September 2, 2016 14:17_

It's OK to only show 10 in the `File > Open Recent` menu, but we should't limit ourselves to only 10 recent folders when going through with <kbd>Ctrl R</kbd>.

data.title: [settings] error in "http.proxyAuthorization"
data.body:
- Open the user settings
- looks at the error view: there's an error on "http.proxyAuthorization"

If 'null is a valid value, specify `types: ['null', 'string' ]` in the JSON schema for the default value.

data.title: Expand Selection To Tag (Ctrl + Shift + A)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Working with HTML, I found this "expand selection to tag" feature very useful on other editors.

I'd LOVE to have this on vscode!  Hopefully others agree.

![expand select to tag](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6314163/18207095/a3097d58-70f7-11e6-88b8-06d718e96b5c.gif)

If your cursor is anywhere on the lorem line after the first < then Ctrl + Shift + A will select just lorem ipsum.

Then repeating that keystroke will expand the selection to the p tags, and then up the tree.

*Not sure how to add [feature-request] label :(
